title: Rolling - two spheres rolling down ramp

content.description: A sphere of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>, radius <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math>, and rotational inertia <math alttext="two fifths m r squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac><mi>m</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mstyle></math> is released from rest at the top of a ramp of height <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi></math>, as shown. The sphere rolls down the ramp without slipping and when it reaches the bottom of the ramp, the sphere has rotational kinetic energy <math alttext="K sub r 1, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>r1</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> and angular speed <math alttext="omega sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. A second sphere of the same radius but with mass <math alttext="2 m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></math> is released from rest from the same location as the first sphere. The second sphere rolls down the ramp without slipping and when it reaches the bottom of the ramp, the sphere has rotational kinetic energy <math alttext="K sub r 2, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>r2</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> and angular speed <math alttext="omega sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math>.
